answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
There are a lot of variables to be weighed when looking at the number of dispatchers needed. NENA and APCO provide the following link which may answer some of the questions: http://www.911dispatch.com/info/QandA1.html
Numbers will be most affected by the services that are being dispatched and the investment in technology throughout the communication area. A center can have people manually entering every piece of information or it may take advantage of the technology that assists in achieving outcomes. Are vehicles in the field able to use touch screens to record time stamps for when they enter service, conduct traffic stops, clear from scenes, prepare reports, or issue citations? Does the person in the field have the capability to check driver status, warrant information, or wanted data? 
Technology can alleviate the need for voice transmission (and reduce the likelihood of error) but it does require an investment and strategic plan for implementation.  Anytime someone mentions "officers or dispatchers per population," a manager should automatically become suspicious.  The key variable is workload and what time is required that translates into numbers of staffing.

author: Brant Hanson
text: As the police department develops their strategic plan, they asked me to find out if there is any research that recommends a police dispatch to population ratio. Is there any theories that are recommended or what is your strategic plan use as a formula? I have only conducted preliminary research at this point and any assistance will be greatly appreciated. Thanks for your time.
title: Police Dispatch to Population Ratio
